summary: Heroin addict Mark Renton (Ewan McGregor) stumbles through bad ideas and sobriety attempts with his unreliable friends -- Sick Boy (Jonny Lee Miller), Begbie (Robert Carlyle), Spud (Ewen Bremner) and Tommy (Kevin McKidd). He also has an underage girlfriend, Diane (Kelly Macdonald), along for the ride. After cleaning up and moving from Edinburgh to London, Mark finds he can't escape the life he left behind when Begbie shows up at his front door on the lam, and a scheming Sick Boy follows.

So my favorite story about this film is that I have a Scottish grandmother who would go to our local arthouse theater anytime there was a new movie set in Scotland. Well, here's a new movie about heroin addicts set in her hometown of Edinburgh. I did not watch TRAINSPOTTING with my grandmother, but I do remember asking her what she thought about it and her response was, "I'd forgotten how much people swear in Scotland."

I was pretty excited about this film when it came out because I loved director Danny Boyles' prior film with Ewan McGregor, SHALLOW GRAVE, a jet-black comedy about a group of friends whose new flatmate turns up dead with a suitcase full of cash under his bed. They then struggle whether to keep the money and dispose of the body or do the right thing by going to the authorities. You can guess which direction they go. TRAINSPOTTING is equally dark in its humor but is far more hard-hitting in its take on drug addiction and drug culture. Besides stylish direction, a great cast, a sharply written script, and one of the best soundtracks of all time, I think what sets this film apart from other tales of addiction is that it dared to show the "fun" and attraction of the drug addict lifestyle; robbing, conning, and the pleasures of the high of drugs. However, the film goes incredibly dark when the addition get uglier and uglier. I think REQUIEM FOR A DREAM is the only film about addiction that is even harder to watch. While REQUIEM is a masterpiece, it's so hard to watch, it's not a film I really want to revisit, though TRAINSPOTTING, as hard as it is to watch at times, is a fantastic cast of characters who are fun to revisit over and over again (like a drugged addicted British version of the kids in DAZED AND CONFUSED). I still have not watched the T2 sequel because I worry it will not live up to the original, but I should probably go ahead and watch it to see where my drug-addict friends are now in their lives.

The chaotic portrait of a generation torn by heroin is the nihilist shout of a reckless youth.
In "Trainspotting", drama, comedy and grotesque mix together giving life to a dynamic and provocative cult, which establishes itself as one of the most influential films of the 90's.
The macrocosm constituted by the squalid outskirts of Edinburgh is a bittersweet choral work that, without any pretentiousness, makes us reflect on how life should be lived.
Through the frenetic editing and the raw and satirical representation of drug addiction, "Trainspotting" places no limits on the freedom of expression of the cinematographic medium.
Boyle's kinetic and disruptive style is difficult to classify but, similarly to the productions of some of his contemporaries (Tarantino or Fincher, for example), can be identified some fundamental elements of the cinema of the end of the century: the power of the dialogues, the use of excellent pop tracks as soundtrack, the violence and controversy of the themes. However, unlike Tarantino or Anderson, he does not use an intricate or tortuous language, but a direct and genuine one, able to reach a wide and varied audience. He leads us to sympathize with the protagonists, to reflect on their morality; always with irony and never really condemning their insolence or their immaturity. They are young people who have chosen to live obfuscated by drugs, in sharp contrast to the merely material value of life giving by the modern man, a slave to the decadent contemporary society, who deludes himself to live truly but who is not so different from those who waste their lives.

Besides, the cinematography of the film is great especially when the whole gang is in one frame. I’m certain that you’ll be moved and inspired by the film.

It seems odd that a film filled with petty criminals, drug addicts, squalor and bloody violence can be so unrelentingly exuberant and joyful.  Such is the case with Danny Boyle's breakthrough movie Trainspotting, the story of a small group of friends in Scotland who somehow manage to subsist on a steady diet of heroin and nicotine, wasting their days either zoning out or hustling to pocket some money to allow further zoning out.  Likable characters, a solid cast, some great music, and witty dialogue keep things moving at a nice clip.  Boyle's direction is inspired, featuring plenty of oddly but effectively composed shots and enough surreal, drug induced scenes to keep things interesting.

I'm sure we've all seen it, but may I take this opportunity to recommend reading Irvine Welsh's source novel if you haven't already. The cast that we all know and love make the characters as engaging and manic as the novel, and Boyle proved his worth once more in T2: Trainspotting, adapting Welsh's Trainspotting sequel Porno with equally impressive effect.

Plays off like a reimagining of Requiem for a Dream with a dash of Eraserhead's surrealism, a heaping helping of humor, and a pumping pop soundtrack. You find yourself drawn to Renton and his gang, but will recognize that they are uniformly terrible people, unable to really bring yourself to root for their success. The upbeat soundtrack creates a clear contrast to the barren prospects of the main cast, the thin veneer of color over the raw core. Performances are uniformly solid, especially McGregor as Renton, Bremner as Spud, and Carlyle as Begby. Trainspotting's reputation is deserved, a fully realized representative of its genre. (4.5/5)

Now a quarter century old, "Trainspotting" stands as truly bulletproof moviemaking. Floating in an artistically liberated air vaguely shared with "Pulp Fiction," Danny Boyle's master class equals Tarantino's in its spiritedness, violence, and drug-centricity. Yet this 1996 black comedy is also imbued with an eviscerating, street-level British intelligence, resulting in a legendary film with a fingerprint all its own.

The structure here is freeing and brilliant. "Trainspotting" is narrated by Mark Renton (Ewan MacGregor), a young street urchin and smack addict whose habit hasn't diluted the venom he spits at Scotland, England, and shoot-up partners Sick Boy (Jonny Lee Miller) and Spud (Ewen Bremner). Once they find heroin, they look to find more. But despite an unchanging end-goal, these are brilliantly sketched characters exhibiting a criminality and shiftlessness that perversely endears.

"Trainspotting" showcases elite storytelling by counterpointing the dehumanization of addiction with a truly vibrant humor. This is a classic of the first order. – WATCHED IT? THEN WATCHLIST: "Being John Malkovich," "True Romance," "Stadium Anthems."

Young heroin addict Mark Renton, Ewan McGregor, is attempting to get himself off drugs while being surrounded by other heroin addicts who he spends most of his time with. One of his friends, the popular and successful soccer player Tommy Mackenzie, Kevin Kidd, is not an addict but the violent and dangerous Begbie, Begbie, Robert Carlyle, is also off drugs and does not present a desirable alternative to a life of drug taking. Sick Boy, Jonny Lee Miller, and Spud Murphy, Ewen Bremner, are his two closest friends who are drug takers and they help each other support their habit. After relapsing with negative effects he is taken in by his reluctant parents and goes cold turkey to get off drugs after narrowly escaping a prison sentence. He is demoralized when he discovers that Mackenzie, who had experimented with drugs previously, has been diagnosed HIV positive and later dies. Begbie begins to drag all of his friends down as he continues to live a life of crime without letting anybody near him escape from his clutch. The friends decide to do a drug deal so that they will have enough money to start anew but this presents several problems for all of them.

What the film gets right is that drug use is not all horror and sickness and feeling bad. There is a reason that people take drugs and this film displays why, for at least brief moments, being on drugs can be a positive experience and take you away from the boredom of everyday life. This group of friends do not want to live like their parents who have probably worked the same job all their lives and never touched illicit substances. In their own way they are free of the restrictions and expectations that society places on men who do try to achieve something with their lives beyond brief highs. None of them appear to have serious jobs and so they are free to discuss James Bond and wander around Edinburgh all day and night chewing the fact. Something about this is romantic as they hold on to the experiences of youth and childhood when there is nothing to do but enjoy yourself and yet when they have no money to pay for drugs and are reminded of their estrangement from their parents life becomes very hard indeed.

Even when Renton descends into hell and has visions of a dead baby crawling on his ceiling the film retains a sense of humor. It's lowest and most painful point is Mackenzie's death as we see a young man with so much potential throw his life away on a drug that will not give him the lasting relief from his break up with his girlfriend that he needs. It is important that this is what pushes Renton to change as making us believe that his parents, who he would seem to have severed ties, are his inspiration for getting clean would have been a stretch. The fact that he changes because of the realization that he is a bad person and has let down a person that he actually cared for makes us want to see him succeed this time. We have come to sympathize with this man as hopeless as he is and do not want to see him destroy any potential he has by taking drugs. At the film's end we feel positive and assume that Renton will reform himself, I will not reveal why, but much like The Lost Weekend (1945) it is left up to us to decide whether our hero will actually manage to shake his crippling addiction.
Although its purely unique oddity may not be for everyone, the ones that Trainspotting's charm does work on will surely recognize the dark comedy/reality of its harsh presentation of drugs.
